entry.title: Dublab
entry.content:
A proposed identity system for an experimental online radio station in Los Angeles that explores the question: how can you draw with sound?

Related project: Order and Chaos
Instructors: Brad Bartlett, Ivan Cruz, Miles Mazzie
Category: Identity, type design, interactive, print
Year: 2018

Future Roots Radio

Dublab is an independent online radio that prides itself on being a hotbed for emerging music, art, and culture. Since 1999, its experimental ethos has attracted musicians including Flying Lotus, Daedelus, and many more.

As a kid in LA, I’ve been a big fan for as long as I can remember. Their tagline ”Future Roots” refers to their style of mixing old and new to create something fresh.


Drawing with Sound

I created a unique tool for making posters and large-scale installations through sound synthesis.

The Processing program works like a feedback loop: images are translated to sound, sound is visualized on the oscilloscope, then that sound is filtered, which affects the image again. It’s like a synthesizer for visuals. The code is based on the open source XYscope library.

A phone running TouchOSC controls the filter value for the sound image.
The Processing sketch used to generate poster linework.

Posters

Custom Typefaces

Two typefaces were developed for Dublab based around sound.

DB Data Mono is a true monospace revival of Data70 in sine- and square wave variants inspired by the concept of Future Roots.

DB Circuit Mono is a connected digital “script” based on the way type is rendered on oscilloscopes.

DB Data Mono
DB Circuit Mono

In Conversation

I met Mark (Dublab’s founder) at an event where he gave a talk on chance in music. Looking to get deeper into my research, I struck up a conversation. He was passionate and excited to share.

I asked directly what interested Mark that Dublab could do more of, and he mentioned that Dublab had a large archive of interviews with musicians that he felt was important to preserve. I took the initiative to propose a print version and transcribe one of the most memorable interviews.

Previous Next

Web

Collateral

Inspired by the concept of Future Roots, dot matrix printing plays a prominent role in the identity. Dot matrix paper becomes an envelope and letter in one.
entry.summary: A proposed identity system for an experimental online radio station in Los Angeles that explores the question: how can you draw with sound? Related project: Order and Chaos Instructors: Brad Bartlett, Ivan Cruz, Miles Mazzie Category: Identity, type design, interactive, print Year: 2018

entry.title: Order and Chaos
entry.content:
An interactive installation inspired by John Cage’s method for composing with chance that gives users the power to create and print their own posters live.

Related project: Dublab
Collaborator: Ali Torbati
Category: Interactive
Year: 2018

Design as Performance

I created a proposed identity for Dublab based on a unique set of tools for graphic creation inspired by sound and music.

This interactive installation allows guests to generate and output their own posters in real time via a hacked dot matrix printer. Rather than a singular event poster, a controlled set of parameters allows for infinite graphic variations with a user’s personal message.

Create your own poster

Installation
entry.summary: An interactive installation inspired by John Cage’s method for composing with chance that gives users the power to create and print their own posters live. Related project: Dublab Collaborator: Ali Torbati Category: Interactive Year: 2018

entry.title: The Blade
entry.content:
An interactive installation celebrating the connective power of the sun and breakthrough LED technology.

Category: Interactive installation
Team: Nik Hafermass, Ivan Cruz, Blossom Liu, Maddie Ma, Danny Grey, Chris Taylor
Year: 2019

Inspired by the Sun

An international tech client wanted to to communicate the power of their revolutionary LED technology — light that embodies the sun. Our team concepted an interactive installation that lets visitors experience the power of pure light on a massive scale.

Process

This project was a first for ArtCenter: a student team collaborating with Triad Berlin and a real-world client. We created small-scale prototypes and VR sketches to iterate quickly and discovered that simple forms best communicated the power of the light. Through its simple form, The Blade shows off the power of these lights in an immediate, immerse manner.

Previous Next

Constant Change Berlin

To celebrate the end of our trip, we threw a party. We designed audio-reactive visuals for the DJs and multi-media installations for guests. I designed the typeface, Platz, used throughout.

We built an audio visualizer in Processing with 12 different code sketches that can be combined for an endless array of visual combinations.
entry.summary: An interactive installation celebrating the connective power of the sun and breakthrough LED technology. Category: Interactive installation Team: Nik Hafermass, Ivan Cruz, Blossom Liu, Maddie Ma, Danny Grey, Chris Taylor Year: 2019

entry.title: Chill by Netflix
entry.content:
A personal care brand extension for Netflix’s sultry side.

Category: Packaging
Instructors: Andrew Gibbs, Jessica Deseo
Year: 2017

Netflix & Chill?

In 2015, “Netflix and chill” had blown up the internet. So when tasked with creating a brand extension in the category of personal care, the answer was obvious. Chill By Netflix is the product line/ad campaign Netflix never knew they needed.

Design Notes

The shape of the packaging references the curve of the logo and is ergonomically designed. Each item features unique illustrated quotes pulled from Netflix original programs related to sex and dating. The full set comes in a single-color printed corrugated mailer, with illustrated quotes celebrating the tongue-in-cheek humor of the brand.

Process

Previous Next
entry.summary: A personal care brand extension for Netflix’s sultry side. Category: Packaging Instructors: Andrew Gibbs, Jessica Deseo Year: 2017

entry.title: Karaoke for Deepfakes
entry.content:
How do you capture content for making the perfect deepfakes in a way that’s fun?

Karaoke.

Category: Interactive installation, motion graphics, video
Instructor: Jennifer Rodenhouse
Year: 2019

Can deepfakes be a design tool?

Deepfakes are videos that uses artificial intelligence and facial pattern recognition to map one person’s face onto another. To create a convincing transfer, all you need two video sources, with one face each, in a variety of angles and expressions. Interviews, speeches, and lectures are best, but what about a passionate karaoke performance of “Heroes” by David Bowie — what if you could, through technology, become your heroes, too?

Requirements for Making a Good Deepfake Video

2 videos, ~1-2 min each

Clearly visible faces

Multiple expressions

Multiple angles

Concept: Heroes — David Bowie

Based on the above criteria, David Bowie’s iconic “Heroes” music video is a perfect candidate for deepfaking.

Set-Up

  • Greenscreen
  • Spotlight
  • Short-throw projector
  • Camera tripod
  • iPhone (as camera)
  • Stool (some used it, some didn’t)

User Test 1: Heroes — David Bowie

For the first test I created a karaoke video for ”Heroes” and used AfterEffects to move the video around on the wall in an attempt to capture more head angles. Afterwards, my first tester, Mikiko, asked: “can I pick my own song?”

User Test 2: Choose Your Own Song

This time I projected a YouTube window and let people pick whatever they wanted. There was no significant improvement by using moving video over normal karaoke video — people naturally move to the music. And it’s more fun.

Learnings

Having fun is the most important thing. Karaoke works best when people have the freedom to express themselves.

  • People naturally move their head when they get into a song.
  • The capture result still meets requirements for a good AI deepfake.
  • The audio isn’t important, only the angles and expressions.
Previous Next

Capture Processing


DeepFaceLab’s interface — if you can call it that.
Previous Next
Extracting frames, then extracting faces with GPU.

Why Deepfake with Karaoke/Entertainers?

“People look at you to see themselves. People want to imagine themselves through you on stage.”

— Klo (musician)
entry.summary: How do you capture content for making the perfect deepfakes in a way that’s fun? Karaoke. Category: Interactive installation, motion graphics, video Instructor: Jennifer Rodenhouse Year: 2019

entry.title: How to Deepfake Yourself
entry.content:
A deep-dive into deepfakes.

Category: Book design
Instructor: Brad Bartlett
Year: 2019

What’s a Deepfake?

A deepfake is an AI-generated video where one face is mapped onto another. The results often have an unreal quality. This is a book investigating deepfakes, computer vision, and related technologies.

Previous Next
This visual treatment comes from Vuforia’s image target engine. It is how a computer recognizes text as image, like a QR code.

Embodying Success

Graduating ArtCenter caused more self-reflection and anxiety than I expected. By embodying successful figures in design and technology, could I shortcut the whole job hunting process and propel my career?

Design authorship as deepfaking myself into Tim Cook, embodying his near-cult presentor status.
Design authorship as deepfaking myself into Elon Musk discussing a future in which simulations are indistinguishable from reality.

Selected Spreads

Since the author is known for talking about symbols, I ran Baudrillard’s famous “Simulation and Simulacra” through a machine learning-based emoji translator. I found the original text nearly impossible to read, so I think that it is an improvement.
DeepFaceLab generates a history of how it “trains” one face to match another — in this case, my own face and Tim Cook’s.
Can I use AI to write my book? GPT-2 is a “natural language text generation model” from OpenAI, considered so good it’s “too dangerous to release.” I used TalkToTransformer.com to generate my conclusions by posing a simple question: What’s a deepfake?
entry.summary: A deep-dive into deepfakes. Category: Book design Instructor: Brad Bartlett Year: 2019
